Additionally, they may handle the loading and unloading of materials, ensuring the smooth progression of production cycles and responding to operational needs.

Occupation: Farmworkers and Laborers, Crop, Nursery, and Greenhouse
Summary: Individuals in this role are actively involved in the cultivation and harvesting of various crops. Their daily duties include planting seeds, tending to plants through weeding and pruning, and preparing the soil by tilling and applying necessary substances. They also operate machinery for these processes. After harvest, they meticulously clean, sort, and pack the produce. This work often involves using hand tools and may extend to repairing equipment and structures, and managing irrigation systems. They are responsible for monitoring crop progress and ensuring quality control. Additionally, they may guide and oversee the work of temporary staff during peak periods, contributing to the overall success of agricultural operations.

Occupation: Farmworkers, Farm, Ranch, and Aquacultural Animals
Summary: Individuals in this role are responsible for the daily care and well-being of living creatures. This involves providing essential sustenance like food and water, and ensuring it is readily available. They monitor the animals' health, observing for any signs of illness or injury, and may administer treatments or contact specialists for more complex medical needs. Tasks also include managing animal movement, such as guiding them to different areas or loading them for transport. Maintaining the cleanliness and functionality of living quarters and equipment is crucial, requiring regular cleaning and repairs. Additionally, they may apply identification marks to animals and keep records to track their condition and characteristics. This work requires careful observation, diligent attention to detail, and the ability to perform a variety of physical tasks.

Individuals in this role are responsible for locating, trapping, and gathering wild animals and aquatic plants and creatures. This involves selecting appropriate tools and methods for setting traps or using various equipment for harvesting. They must monitor conditions, including weather and equipment status, making decisions to ensure operations are conducted safely and effectively. Tasks include operating vessels and navigational instruments, maintaining equipment, and performing minor repairs. They also ensure harvested items meet required standards and manage the loading and unloading of supplies and equipment. This work often requires travel to remote areas and direct interaction with the environment to achieve collection goals.

Individuals in this role perform essential manual labor to develop, maintain, and protect natural areas. They actively participate in planting and nurturing young vegetation and contribute to pest and disease management to safeguard plant health. A key responsibility involves constructing structures designed to manage water flow, prevent soil erosion, and retain vital nutrients. They also engage in fire management, which may include fighting active fires or conducting controlled burns under supervision. This work requires conferring with colleagues to coordinate efforts, discuss operational needs, and ensure safety protocols are followed, all while monitoring equipment for proper functioning and performing related tasks.

Professionals in this role assess trees, considering characteristics like twist, rot, and lean, to determine the safest and most effective cutting strategy. They use specialized equipment to make precise cuts, controlling the direction of the fall and minimizing damage to the tree and surrounding area. This involves clearing work sites, creating escape routes, and strategically placing wedges or jacks. After felling, they often measure and cut trees into specific lengths, ensuring quality and adherence to standards. They are responsible for maintaining their tools and equipment, including cleaning, lubricating, and sharpening them. Additionally, they identify and tag unsafe trees to prevent accidents.

Operators utilize specialized vehicles and equipment to move and process harvested materials. They perform pre-operation inspections and routine maintenance to ensure safety and functionality, making critical decisions regarding equipment operation and control. Their daily activities involve navigating various terrains, manipulating materials with mounted accessories, and transporting them to designated areas. They also engage in tasks such as clearing land and road maintenance. Accurate record-keeping through job or shift reports is essential. Operators must continuously monitor equipment performance and troubleshoot any issues that arise, ensuring efficient and safe completion of their duties. They may also assess material quality against set standards.

Individuals in this role meticulously inspect and evaluate raw materials, often involving precise measurements of volume, weight, and dimensions. They identify and assess material characteristics and defects, applying established criteria to determine grades. This requires careful observation and judgment to ascertain marketable value. They document findings, often using specialized tools or electronic devices to record data. This information is crucial for subsequent processes, ensuring materials are sorted, routed, or processed according to their assessed quality and grade. They may also apply identification marks to materials for tracking and grading purposes, making decisions about how to handle substandard or special-quality items.

Occupation: First-Line Supervisors of Construction Trades and Extraction Workers
Summary: This role involves overseeing and coordinating the daily activities of construction and extraction teams. Key responsibilities include assigning tasks, ensuring work progresses according to specifications, and verifying safety protocols are followed. This position requires reading blueprints and planning procedures, as well as estimating material and personnel needs for upcoming projects. There is a significant focus on problem-solving, whether addressing production issues or equipment malfunctions, and collaborating with various personnel to resolve challenges. Additionally, individuals in this role are responsible for training new team members, ordering necessary supplies, and maintaining accurate operational records. They also contribute to personnel management by recommending actions such as promotions or hires.

These professionals oversee teams responsible for installing solar systems. They assess potential sites, determine design requirements, and ensure installations meet safety and code standards. They coordinate schedules, budgets, and resources, including personnel, equipment, and materials, to manage project timelines effectively. This involves estimating needs, preparing proposals, and purchasing or renting necessary items. They provide technical guidance to installation crews, troubleshoot issues, and monitor the progress of work, including that of subcontractors, to maintain project plans. Additionally, they arrange for necessary inspections and perform initial system testing to confirm functionality before customer implementation, always looking for ways to improve efficiency and reduce costs.

These professionals construct, assemble, maintain, and repair large-scale vessels. They meticulously study blueprints to understand dimensions and relationships between parts, often marking and laying out heavy metal sections. Using various hand and power tools, they position, align, and secure these sections, then shape and join them through methods like welding or bolting. Their work also involves inspecting components for defects, repairing or replacing faulty parts, and ensuring the integrity of joints and fittings. They conduct tests to confirm proper function and may direct cleaning operations. Attention to detail and precision are critical throughout the process to ensure the safe and effective operation of the equipment.

Workers in this role meticulously lay and bind various building materials using mortar to construct or repair structures. They begin by interpreting blueprints and drawings to plan their work, calculating angles and determining alignment. Using tools, they measure, mark, and create guidelines, breaking or cutting materials to size as needed. Workers carefully construct corners and lay courses, ensuring vertical and horizontal accuracy with levels and plumb lines. They apply mortar, remove excess, and finish joints for a uniform appearance. Throughout the process, they monitor their work for quality and may also be responsible for mixing materials and cleaning surfaces. Additionally, they inspect existing brickwork to identify and perform necessary repairs.

Workers in this role prepare and place stone for various construction projects. They begin by interpreting blueprints and laying out project foundations using measuring tools and guidelines. They mix and apply mortar, carefully setting and aligning stone pieces according to precise patterns. They also shape, trim, and cut stone using specialized equipment and hand tools to achieve desired forms. Responsibilities include finishing joints, cleaning excess materials, and ensuring a smooth, attractive final appearance. They also repair existing stone structures by replacing damaged sections or patching cracks. Throughout the process, they manage materials, operate tools safely, and monitor the quality of their work to meet project specifications.

Individuals in this occupation interpret blueprints and project plans to determine necessary materials and dimensions. They meticulously measure and mark materials, then shape or cut them to specified measurements using various tools. They assemble and fasten materials to create frameworks, ensuring structures are plumb and level. This involves installing fixtures like windows, frames, and flooring, and repairing or replacing damaged sections. Safety protocols are strictly followed, and work areas are kept clean. They also maintain records of activities, document progress, and may schedule work crews. Decision-making involves selecting appropriate tools and methods for assembly, installation, and repair tasks, prioritizing structural integrity and adherence to plans.

Individuals in this role prepare surfaces by inspecting for imperfections and making necessary corrections to ensure a smooth foundation. They accurately measure and cut materials according to diagrams and specifications, calculating the quantity needed for the job. They meticulously lay out and install materials, joining edges as required for a seamless finish. They carefully trim and fit materials along edges and openings, ensuring secure attachment using various methods. Throughout the process, they manage resources, including the removal of old materials and furniture, and maintain a clean worksite. They also perform quality control checks, make adjustments for optimal appearance and durability, and complete the installation by fastening necessary hardware.

Occupation: Floor Layers, Except Carpet, Wood, and Hard Tiles
Summary: Professionals in this role prepare surfaces for new coverings by cleaning, smoothing, and ensuring they are firm and dry. They meticulously measure and mark guidelines, cutting materials to fit precisely around obstacles and for specific designs. Their day involves applying adhesives and then laying out, positioning, and adhering shock-absorbing, sound-deadening, or decorative coverings to floors and other surfaces. This requires careful attention to detail to keep courses straight and ensure tight joints. They also trim excess materials and roll or press the coverings to create a smooth, finished appearance. Responsibilities include removing old coverings and any necessary fixtures before beginning the installation process, and ensuring the final surface is free of excess adhesive.

Individuals in this role prepare and treat wooden surfaces to achieve a desired aesthetic and protective finish. They begin by inspecting the surface, meticulously scraping and sanding edges and difficult-to-reach areas to ensure a uniform smoothness. Using specialized equipment, they guide sanding machines over the entire surface until it is completely smooth, removing imperfections and old coatings. After ensuring the surface is clean and free of debris, they apply protective coatings and sealants. This involves careful application of materials and often multiple layers, with attention to detail to guarantee the quality and durability of the final outcome. They also monitor their work throughout the process to maintain high standards.

This role involves carefully preparing surfaces, often by removing old materials or applying coatings, before applying durable tiles and stones. Professionals measure and mark areas according to plans, ensuring precise layouts and patterns for a desired aesthetic. They mix and apply adhesives or mortars, cut materials to fit specific spaces and around obstacles, and then meticulously set them in place. Levels and straightedges are used to ensure alignment. Tasks also include finishing joints, applying sealants to protect surfaces, and sometimes repairing or replacing damaged sections. This work requires attention to detail, problem-solving for complex layouts, and coordinating actions for accurate installation.

Individuals in this role are responsible for preparing, pouring, and finishing concrete surfaces. They begin by setting and aligning forms that will contain the concrete, ensuring they are correctly positioned for the desired pitch and depth. They then direct the placement and spreading of concrete, using tools to level and smooth the material. Throughout the process, they monitor environmental factors that might affect how the concrete cures. They also use specialized tools to shape edges, create expansion joints, and apply hardening or sealing compounds. Additionally, they may install fixtures, repair existing concrete by patching or grinding, and prepare surfaces for further treatment.

Individuals in this role prepare and apply mixtures for durable and decorative surfaces. They meticulously measure and combine ingredients, ensuring proper consistency for application. Their work involves spreading, leveling, and smoothing these mixtures using various tools. They also install division strips to create designs or prevent cracking, and embed chips or other decorative elements into the surface. Once applied, they grind and polish the material to achieve the desired finish, sometimes using portable equipment for intricate areas. Finally, they clean, seal, and cure the surfaces, ensuring a smooth, uniform, and long-lasting result. This requires careful monitoring of materials and procedures, along with precise execution.

Individuals in this role perform essential physical labor at various work sites. They prepare the area by clearing debris, digging trenches, and compacting earth to specifications. They often operate and maintain a variety of tools and equipment, ensuring they are functioning properly and safely. These workers might signal operators to guide the movement of materials and machinery. They also read plans to understand work requirements, measure and mark areas for construction, and load or unload materials, distributing them as needed. Additionally, they may assist other craftspeople with their tasks, contributing to the overall project completion.

Occupation: Paving, Surfacing, and Tamping Equipment Operators
Summary: Operators use specialized equipment to apply paving materials like concrete and asphalt, or to compact various substances such as gravel and dirt. They manage the operation of machinery by starting, controlling levers, and guiding the equipment along defined paths. This involves filling machines with materials, regulating flow rates, and monitoring the distribution of substances to make adjustments. Operators also coordinate with material delivery vehicles, ensuring a steady supply. Beyond operation, they perform essential maintenance, including cleaning, inspecting, and repairing equipment, or reporting issues. They are responsible for setting up and dismantling equipment, and ensuring the compacted surfaces meet specific requirements. Some roles may also involve traffic control and the operation of auxiliary vehicles.

Operators utilize specialized heavy equipment to drive foundational elements into the ground. They meticulously maneuver controls to position leads and hammers, carefully hoisting and aligning components before activation. By operating power hammers or drophammers, they drive these elements to precise depths, ensuring structural integrity. Daily routines involve conducting thorough pre-operational checks to confirm equipment readiness, performing essential cleaning, lubrication, and refueling to maintain optimal performance. Operators must also monitor equipment function throughout operation, making adjustments as needed to ensure the work meets required specifications. This role demands a strong focus on equipment operation, control, and maintenance for successful project completion.

Occupation: Operating Engineers and Other Construction Equipment Operators
Summary: Individuals in this role control and operate various types of powered machinery used in construction and related activities. They maneuver equipment to excavate, move, and grade earth, prepare sites, or assist in constructing foundations and paving surfaces. This involves starting engines, using controls to manipulate attachments, and carefully aligning machines with project guidelines and signals from colleagues. They also identify potential hazards, such as underground utilities, and take steps to avoid them, ensuring compliance with safety standards. Additionally, they perform routine checks, make adjustments, and conduct basic repairs to maintain equipment functionality and document operational details.

Professionals in this role carefully read specifications and blueprints to plan their installation work. They measure and mark surfaces, ensuring accuracy before cutting and fitting various materials onto frameworks. This involves precise measurement and cutting of panels or tiles to create openings for fixtures and to fit surrounding areas. They work with both structural components, assembling and installing metal or wooden framing, and finishing materials. Coordination with other trades is essential, particularly with those who finish seams. Responsibilities include inspecting surfaces for proper alignment and ensuring secure fastening of all installed components. In some cases, they may also prepare surfaces by removing old materials before beginning new installations.

Professionals in this role meticulously prepare surfaces for final finishing. They carefully examine materials, selecting appropriate compounds and tapes to ensure durability and adhesion. Day-to-day tasks involve precisely applying sealing compounds and embedding tape over joints, cracks, and fasteners using various tools. They spread, smooth, and feather these materials to create seamless transitions between surfaces, often applying multiple coats. Workers may also counter-sink fasteners, repair imperfections, and sand rough areas to achieve a uniformly smooth finish. They manage their workflow efficiently, often working at heights and ensuring all materials meet quality standards before proceeding to the next stage of surface preparation.

Individuals in this occupation plan and install electrical systems by interpreting blueprints and applying relevant codes. They assemble, connect, and test wiring, equipment, and fixtures, often working from heights or in confined spaces using various tools. They diagnose and troubleshoot malfunctions, performing repairs or replacements to ensure systems are safe and functional. This involves inspecting components for defects, advising on operational safety, and sometimes directing the work of others. They may also create preliminary sketches, estimate costs, and maintain records related to installations and repairs, ensuring all work complies with established standards and regulations.

Workers in this role interpret blueprints and specifications to guide their work, determining the correct size, shape, and type of materials needed. They measure dimensions precisely and mark outlines for cutting glass accurately. Using specialized tools, they cut, fit, and install glass into various frameworks, ensuring proper alignment and secure placement with hardware and fastening materials. This involves preparing surfaces, fabricating or installing supporting structures, and assembling components. They also handle the transportation of materials, loading and unloading large pieces using lifting equipment when necessary. Removal of old or broken glass and preparation of the work area are also key responsibilities. Following safety procedures and using appropriate equipment are critical throughout the installation and finishing processes.

Occupation: Insulation Workers, Floor, Ceiling, and Wall
Summary: Individuals in this role apply insulating materials to various structures, focusing on floors, ceilings, and walls. Their daily activities involve carefully measuring and cutting insulation to fit specific areas using a range of tools. They then meticulously fit, wrap, staple, or glue these materials into place, ensuring even distribution and proper coverage. This process often requires reading blueprints to select the correct insulation type and understanding its properties. They also prepare surfaces by applying adhesives or fasteners, and may remove old insulation, adhering to safety protocols. Operating specialized equipment to apply blown insulation and sealing finished surfaces are also key responsibilities. Effective time management and attention to detail are crucial for successful application and completion of tasks.

Workers in this role carefully read blueprints and specifications to understand project requirements. They measure and cut various insulating materials, selecting the appropriate type based on the need for heat retention or exclusion. Surface preparation involves applying adhesives or fasteners. They then apply, remove, and repair insulation on mechanical systems, fitting it around obstructions and shaping it as needed. This includes covering and sealing surfaces to protect the insulation from damage and environmental factors. Decisions are made regarding the amount and type of insulation required, as well as installation methods, considering factors like location and equipment use. Throughout the process, they monitor their work and ensure quality control.

Individuals in this role prepare surfaces for finishing by cleaning, sanding, and filling imperfections. They mix colors to achieve desired hues and consistencies and apply various finishes using brushes, rollers, or sprayers to structures and equipment. This involves selecting appropriate materials and tools, and ensuring proper adhesion and durability. They may also perform tasks such as setting up ladders or scaffolding for access, and protecting surrounding areas with coverings. Reading work orders and instructions guides their daily activities, ensuring the specified requirements are met. They also make calculations for material needs and costs.

Individuals in this occupation prepare interior surfaces by cleaning, repairing imperfections, and applying sealants or adhesives to ensure proper adhesion. They measure and cut decorative materials according to job requirements. Then, they meticulously apply these materials to walls and ceilings, carefully aligning patterns and smoothing out wrinkles or bubbles with specialized tools. A key part of the role involves ensuring the finished work is neatly aligned, patterns match, and seams are invisible. They also remove old coverings, prepare surfaces, and set up necessary equipment. Throughout the process, they make decisions regarding material application, alignment, and final quality checks to achieve a smooth and visually appealing finish.

Individuals in this role prepare and install underground conduits for water and waste systems. They meticulously grade and level trenches according to specifications, often using various tools and equipment. Their work involves cutting pipes to precise lengths and carefully positioning them for connection. A key responsibility is ensuring secure and watertight joints through methods like welding or sealing. They utilize instruments to verify slopes and alignment, referencing blueprints and instructions. Additionally, they may operate heavy machinery, manage materials, and perform repairs on existing systems, ensuring the integrity and functionality of the infrastructure.

Individuals in this role examine blueprints and building codes to plan the layout, installation, and repair of pipe systems. They meticulously measure and mark structures to identify the placement for pipes and passages, ensuring accurate installations. They cut, shape, and assemble various pipe materials using a range of tools, connecting them with appropriate fittings and securing them to structures. After installation, they conduct tests to detect and locate leaks, ensuring the integrity of the system. They also maintain and repair existing systems by replacing worn components or clearing blockages. This work requires careful monitoring of system operations and adherence to specifications for a safe and functional outcome.

These professionals install and repair systems that collect and circulate solar-heated water. They assess potential sites, ensuring structural integrity and optimal orientation for collectors. Their work involves mounting devices, installing collectors, and connecting various components like pumps, controllers, sensors, and water heaters using plumbing and electrical techniques. They meticulously apply sealants and weatherproofing to roof penetrations. After assembly, they test system functionality, check for leaks, and fill water tanks. They also perform routine maintenance and repairs to keep systems operational. Additionally, they are responsible for identifying potential hazards and demonstrating proper system operation, maintenance, and safety procedures to owners.

Professionals in this role prepare and apply various coating materials to interior and exterior surfaces. They begin by cleaning and preparing surfaces, ensuring they are ready for application. This often involves setting up protective coverings and scaffolding. They mix plaster or stucco to the correct consistency, sometimes overseeing others who perform this task. Using specialized tools, they carefully apply multiple coats, working to achieve desired textures and finishes. They also install insulation systems and ensure the undercoat is properly textured to promote adhesion of subsequent layers. Throughout the process, they manage materials, maintain a clean worksite, and make judgments to ensure quality outcomes.

Workers in this occupation meticulously interpret blueprints and instructions to determine the precise quantities, sizes, shapes, and placements of reinforcement materials. They prepare these materials by cutting them to specific lengths and shapes, sometimes using specialized machines or torches. The core of their work involves carefully positioning and securing steel bars, rods, cables, or mesh within concrete forms. This is achieved by fastening them together using wire, pliers, or other tools, ensuring they are correctly spaced and held in place, often with blocks to maintain proper elevation. They operate various tools and machines to cut, bend, and position these structural components, ensuring the integrity of the final concrete structure through precise installation of reinforcing elements.

Individuals in this role prepare structures for covering by removing debris and setting up necessary access points. They assess roof conditions to determine appropriate repair or installation methods. Tasks include cutting and layering various materials, such as shingles, slate, asphalt, or membranes, to create waterproof and insulated surfaces. They also seal joints and exposed fasteners to prevent leaks. Some may spray protective coatings or install additional features like ventilation systems and skylights. This work requires careful measurement, material application, and adherence to safety protocols to ensure the structural integrity and protection of buildings.

Individuals in this role interpret blueprints and specifications to determine project requirements, including materials and assembly sequences. They meticulously measure and mark dimensions on various materials before cutting, shaping, and bending them using specialized equipment and hand tools. Following fabrication, they assemble components by fastening seams and joints through methods like welding or riveting. They also install fabricated parts into supportive frameworks, ensuring proper fit and function. Routine maintenance and repairs are performed on equipment. Occasionally, they may be responsible for supervising apprentices or new hires and transporting materials to work sites, ensuring all tasks are completed according to precise standards.

Professionals in this role meticulously follow blueprints and specifications to erect structural frameworks. They prepare and position steel components, connecting them with precision using various tools and fasteners. This involves hoisting heavy members into place, ensuring accurate alignment with specialized equipment, and securing them for permanent joining. They may also fabricate custom metal parts and assemble prefabricated units. Responsibilities include coordinating with equipment operators, verifying the integrity of connections, and making necessary adjustments to ensure structural soundness and adherence to design plans. This work requires careful monitoring, critical thinking, and effective problem-solving to manage complex construction tasks safely and efficiently.

Professionals in this field meticulously assemble and install systems designed to harness solar energy. They interpret site assessments and schematics to position and secure structural framing and energy-capturing components. This involves careful measurement, cutting, and bolting of materials to ensure structural integrity and optimal orientation. They also perform crucial electrical tasks, including verifying wiring, checking currents, and ensuring proper grounding and connections. Identifying and mitigating electrical, environmental, and safety hazards is paramount throughout the process. Furthermore, they test the functionality of installed systems, make necessary adjustments, and document their work to ensure compliance and performance.

Occupation: Helpers--Brickmasons, Blockmasons, Stonemasons, and Tile and Marble Setters
Summary: This role involves providing essential support to skilled tradespeople in construction and finishing. Responsibilities include mixing various construction materials according to specific formulas, preparing surfaces by removing old materials or cleaning, and transporting materials, tools, and equipment to and from work areas. The role also entails supplying specified materials to craftspeople and assisting in the installation or repair of surfaces. Individuals in this role will operate tools and machines to cut materials to size, apply finishing agents like grout or sealants, and maintain a clean and organized work environment. Attention to detail is crucial for preparing surfaces, removing excess materials, and ensuring all tools and materials are properly stored.

Individuals in this role support skilled craftspeople by performing essential preparatory and support tasks. They are responsible for gathering and transporting necessary materials and tools to the work site. A key part of their daily routine involves precise cutting and shaping of materials to specified dimensions, as well as positioning and holding these materials steady for fastening. They also prepare surfaces by smoothing and sanding, and ensure the work area remains clean and safe by removing debris and maintaining equipment. This includes tasks like erecting scaffolding and preparing concrete forms, all while following instructions and ensuring accurate alignment and measurements for the project's success.

These individuals support skilled professionals by performing various hands-on tasks. They prepare materials by measuring, cutting, bending, and stripping wires, and then assist in their installation. This involves drilling holes, pulling wires through conduits, and securing components using hand tools. They are responsible for maintaining a clean and organized work environment, ensuring tools and equipment are in good working order. They also transport necessary supplies and materials to work sites. Their duties include identifying and addressing issues like loose connections or worn parts, and disassembling and reassembling equipment as needed. They follow instructions to facilitate the completion of electrical installations and repairs.

Occupation: Helpers--Painters, Paperhangers, Plasterers, and Stucco Masons
Summary: Individuals in this role provide essential support to skilled craftspeople. They prepare work areas by applying protective coverings to guard against damage or staining and may erect scaffolding for access. A significant part of their day involves cleaning work sites and equipment to ensure a safe and orderly environment. They are responsible for supplying and holding necessary tools and materials for the primary workers, anticipating needs and ensuring a smooth workflow. Additionally, they perform tasks such as filling minor imperfections in surfaces, contributing to the overall quality of the finished project. These duties require careful attention to instructions and a proactive approach to assisting the team.

Individuals in this role provide support by supplying and holding necessary materials and tools for skilled professionals. They often prepare the work area by cleaning it and its equipment. Their tasks involve measuring, cutting, and assembling components, as well as drilling holes to accommodate their installation. They may also assist in the fitting of various assemblies and components, ensuring proper placement and support. This includes mounting brackets and hangers, and preparing the site for installation. When necessary, they are responsible for disassembling and removing damaged or worn parts, and maintaining a clean and organized workspace throughout the process.

Individuals in this role provide essential support to skilled tradespeople by performing less specialized tasks. They are responsible for preparing work areas, which includes cleaning and organizing, as well as maintaining tools and equipment. A significant part of their day involves handling and transporting materials and tools to and from the work site, often by carrying them up ladders or using hoisting equipment. They also assist directly with the application of roofing materials by unrolling, positioning, and securing them under supervision. Additionally, they help remove old materials, ensure the work area is clear of debris, and may perform basic maintenance tasks such as clearing drains and downspouts to ensure the integrity of the structure.

Individuals in this role conduct thorough examinations of structures, systems, and installations, meticulously comparing them against established plans, specifications, and regulatory standards. They review blueprints and site layouts to ensure adherence to legal and safety requirements, often issuing permits for various construction activities. By employing specialized tools and measurement devices, they verify dimensions, alignment, and structural integrity, documenting their findings with detailed notes and photographic evidence. These professionals engage in critical decision-making to determine compliance, identify potential issues, and confer with relevant parties to explain findings and propose necessary corrective actions. They also monitor ongoing work to ensure proper execution and safety throughout the process.

This role involves conducting comprehensive assessments of various systems to evaluate energy consumption. Professionals examine building envelopes, mechanical systems, and process operations, collecting and analyzing field data, including energy bills and usage measurements. They identify opportunities for enhanced operational efficiency and reduced energy use, calculating potential savings and analyzing the technical feasibility of proposed measures. Recommendations for energy-efficient technologies or alternative sources are developed, along with reports detailing findings and potential cost savings. This includes identifying health or safety concerns, performing tests to locate air leaks, and ensuring proper installation and performance of new energy-efficient equipment. They also educate individuals on efficiency practices and answer related questions.

Occupation: Elevator and Escalator Installers and Repairers
Summary: Professionals in this field install, assemble, maintain, and repair mechanical and electrical systems for vertical and horizontal transportation. They meticulously inspect wiring, control panels, and moving parts, ensuring proper alignment and clearance. When malfunctions occur, they troubleshoot and diagnose issues using specialized testing equipment, then disassemble units to repair or replace worn or broken components. They work from blueprints to understand system layouts and select appropriate tools and equipment for installation and repair tasks. Compliance with safety regulations and building codes is a critical aspect of their work, documented through detailed reports and logbooks. These individuals ensure the safe and efficient operation of complex equipment through skilled repair, maintenance, and adherence to specifications.

Individuals in this role are responsible for constructing and repairing various types of barriers, walls, and gates. They begin by assessing project needs, which includes communicating with customers to understand their requirements and providing price estimates. A crucial part of their work involves carefully measuring and marking fence lines, then preparing the ground by digging postholes and ensuring the area is free from underground utilities. They meticulously set posts, ensuring they are plumb and secure, often by embedding them in concrete or compacted soil. Subsequently, they assemble and attach framing, stretch and secure fencing materials, and construct or repair gates. This process demands precision in cutting and fitting materials, using a variety of hand and power tools, and sometimes welding metal components.

Individuals in this role are responsible for the safe identification, containment, removal, and disposal of hazardous substances. They meticulously prepare work areas by building containment structures and then use various tools and equipment to extract contaminated materials. This involves careful handling, packing, and loading of substances for transport and proper disposal, adhering strictly to safety protocols and regulations. They also clean contaminated equipment and sites, ensuring that all materials are managed responsibly and safely. Decision-making is critical in assessing risks, selecting appropriate methods, and operating machinery effectively to prevent further contamination and ensure environmental safety. Monitoring and quality control are ongoing throughout the process.

Individuals in this role focus on the upkeep and repair of infrastructure, particularly roadways and associated areas. Their daily activities involve operating vehicles and equipment to perform repairs on pavement, guardrails, and drainage systems. They also manage vegetation by clearing brush and mowing, and ensure safety by setting up traffic control devices and warning motorists. These professionals conduct routine inspections and maintenance on vehicles and tools to ensure operational readiness. They are responsible for clearing debris, including snow and litter, from pathways and structures. This work requires attention to detail, problem-solving skills, and the ability to operate various tools and machinery effectively to maintain functional and safe conditions.

Occupation: Rail-Track Laying and Maintenance Equipment Operators
Summary: These operators are responsible for the construction and upkeep of rail lines. They operate specialized machinery to lay new track, making precise adjustments to ensure proper alignment and levelness. Daily tasks involve monitoring equipment performance, performing routine maintenance, and lubricating components. They also conduct repairs on various track elements, such as switches, and may weld sections of rail. Safety is paramount, requiring careful observation of indicators and adherence to operational controls. Operators also perform cleaning duties, clearing debris, snow, or ice from the tracks and ensuring ballast is properly maintained. When needed, they troubleshoot issues and perform repairs to keep the rail infrastructure in optimal condition.

Occupation: Septic Tank Servicers and Sewer Pipe Cleaners
Summary: Individuals in this role are responsible for maintaining and repairing underground systems that carry waste materials. They use specialized equipment to clear blockages and inspect lines for issues, often identifying problems using diagnostic tools. A significant part of their day involves operating machinery to clean pipes and tanks, and performing manual labor like digging when necessary. They meticulously document all maintenance and repair actions taken. This work also requires coordinating with team members, potentially driving vehicles to transport necessary tools and personnel, and performing routine checks and minor repairs on their own equipment to ensure operational readiness and safety. Making decisions based on problem analysis is key.

Professionals in this role prepare the ground for installation by removing unsuitable materials, compacting soil, and ensuring proper drainage. They then supply and place base materials, bedding sand, and edge restraints. Decisions are made regarding paver layouts, patterns, and precise markings for alignment. They cut paving units to size using specialized tools and carefully set them, ensuring correct spacing. After placing the pavers, they compact the bedding sand and the units themselves to create a finished surface. Finally, they fill the joints with sand, compacting to ensure they are full, and sweep excess sand from the completed area.

Professionals in this field assess structures to identify areas needing improvement for energy efficiency. They perform diagnostic tests on heating, cooling, and air flow systems to detect issues like air leakage. Based on these assessments, they execute various improvements. This includes installing insulation in attics, walls, and crawl spaces, as well as sealing ducts and openings to prevent energy loss. They also conduct minor repairs to components like windows and walls, and apply materials to reduce drafts. Furthermore, they explain conservation measures and recommendations to clients, ensuring proper understanding of the work performed and its benefits. Maintaining accurate records of activities and materials used is also a key responsibility.

Individuals in this role are responsible for the operation and maintenance of derrick equipment and associated pumps. They conduct regular inspections of derricks to identify potential flaws and ensure optimal working conditions through cleaning and lubrication. A key duty involves controlling the characteristics of drilling fluids, which includes mixing components, weighing materials, and preparing mud reports for crew members. They monitor pump operations, listening for unusual sounds or vibrations, and make necessary repairs to pumps and related equipment. Additionally, they manage the circulation of fluids through drill pipes, assist with pipe handling, and ensure proper assembly and alignment of derrick components. They may also oversee and train crew members on operational procedures and chemical handling.

Occupation: Rotary Drill Operators, Oil and Gas
Summary: These professionals operate and maintain specialized equipment to extract underground resources or collect geological samples. They closely monitor operational performance, making adjustments to controls like throttles and levers to regulate equipment speed and pressure. Their day involves connecting and disconnecting equipment components, maintaining machinery through lubrication and part replacement, and troubleshooting issues to ensure smooth operations. They meticulously record details about the drilling process, including depth, materials used, and encountered geological formations. Additionally, they oversee and instruct crew members, ensuring safety protocols are followed and guiding activities such as equipment setup and well servicing. They prepare necessary materials, like drilling fluids, and manage the removal of samples for analysis.

Occupation: Service Unit Operators, Oil and Gas
Summary: These professionals operate specialized equipment to enhance the flow of resources from producing wells or to retrieve items stuck in wells. They perform regular safety inspections on tools and equipment, and listen closely to machinery to identify any operational issues or unusual conditions. When necessary, they install specialized pressure-control devices. They analyze instrument readings to determine the depth of obstructions, and use their judgment to select appropriate methods and tools for removing obstacles. Communication with colleagues is essential for gathering critical information about well conditions and equipment. They also maintain detailed records of services performed, tools utilized, and time spent, often driving specialized units to various work locations.

Occupation: Excavating and Loading Machine and Dragline Operators, Surface Mining
Summary: Operators control heavy machinery to excavate and move loose materials. They receive instructions about material movement and excavation needs, then interpret digging plans and machine capabilities to perform tasks. This involves operating levers, pedals, and controls to manipulate equipment according to specifications, often guided by signals or markings. Operators ensure machinery is set up and inspected before use, performing routine lubrication, adjustments, and repairs, including replacing worn parts. They monitor operations for safety and efficiency, manage various site conditions like slides or cleanings, and create or maintain inclines and ramps. Regular maintenance and troubleshooting are key to ensuring equipment functions correctly and safely for the intended operations.

Occupation: Earth Drillers, Except Oil and Gas
Summary: Individuals in this role operate specialized equipment to create holes in the earth. They meticulously select and attach appropriate drilling tools, then control the equipment to bore into various materials, adjusting settings based on subsurface conditions. Their daily work involves precisely positioning and stabilizing machinery, managing the insertion of casings, and regulating speed and pressure to achieve desired depths and alignments. They regularly monitor operations, perform essential maintenance and repairs on equipment, and document progress and geological findings. These professionals also manage logistical aspects, including transporting equipment to work sites and ensuring tools are properly assembled and maintained for safe and effective operation.

Occupation: Explosives Workers, Ordnance Handling Experts, and Blasters
Summary: Individuals in this role are responsible for carefully placing and detonating explosive materials. They assess blast areas to determine the precise type and quantity of explosives required, while rigorously adhering to safety regulations. This involves preparing blast sites, positioning charges, and connecting initiation systems to achieve timed sequences. They ensure all personnel are safely cleared before initiating detonations. Additionally, responsibilities include managing the storage, transport, and inventory of materials, maintaining detailed records, and performing necessary maintenance on equipment. Decision-making is critical for ensuring safety and operational success in complex environments.

These professionals operate specialized machinery to extract and move materials from underground locations. They control the equipment using various levers and controls, ensuring continuous operation and efficient material transfer to transport systems. A significant part of their day involves monitoring the machinery's performance, listening for any unusual sounds that might indicate malfunctions, and taking immediate action to address them. They also perform routine maintenance, such as cleaning, oiling, and replacing worn parts, to keep the equipment in optimal working condition. Additionally, they assess the safety of the work area, checking for structural stability and air quality, and make necessary adjustments to ventilation systems. They must make critical decisions regarding equipment positioning and operation to maximize productivity and ensure safety.

Individuals in this role operate specialized machinery to install essential support systems underground. They meticulously drill holes into overhead structures at precise intervals, ensuring stability by securing them with various anchoring devices. This process involves carefully positioning equipment, inserting and operating drilling tools, and then firmly inserting and tightening anchor bolts. They also assess and remove unstable materials, conduct safety checks, and perform tests to monitor environmental conditions. Maintaining equipment through routine checks and repairs is a key responsibility. Additionally, they may manage airflow systems and ensure that installed supports meet required tension and safety standards before proceeding to the next area, demonstrating a commitment to structural integrity and operational safety.

Occupation: Loading and Moving Machine Operators, Underground Mining
Summary: Operators control specialized machinery to load and move materials such as coal, rock, and ore. They maneuver equipment to gather materials and direct them into transport systems like cars or conveyors. This involves operating levers and controls to position booms or shovels precisely. They also drive vehicles to designated discharge points, ensuring loads are properly transferred. Daily responsibilities include monitoring the loading process for accuracy, clearing obstructions from paths, and maintaining equipment through cleaning, fueling, and minor repairs. They must also manage power cables and adhere to safety signals and guidelines while performing their duties.

Workers in this role meticulously examine large stone masses, identifying natural patterns and lines to guide their actions. They operate specialized equipment to carefully separate desired blocks from the main formations. This involves precise insertion of tools and controlled application of force to achieve clean breaks. They also mark the stone, indicating dimensions and outlines to ensure accurate cuts. Decision-making is critical for selecting the best methods to split the material according to specifications, managing resources effectively, and ensuring the quality of the separated pieces. Continuous monitoring of equipment and work progress is essential for safety and efficiency.

Individuals in this role perform essential hands-on tasks related to the setup, maintenance, and repair of specialized equipment. They routinely use various hand and power tools to assemble, disassemble, and secure components, ensuring operational integrity. This involves tasks such as tightening or loosening pipes and rods, bolting engine parts together, and guiding heavy materials. They also conduct inspections to identify and fix issues like leaks in flow lines, often employing specialized detection methods. Additionally, their responsibilities include moving materials, laying pipelines, and maintaining vehicles used in operations. This requires careful attention to detail, coordination with others, and the ability to troubleshoot and resolve mechanical challenges effectively.

Individuals in this role provide essential support for skilled craft workers. Their day-to-day activities involve monitoring equipment performance, identifying potential issues, and assisting with adjustments to machinery used in extraction processes. They are responsible for transporting materials and parts to work sites, often operating vehicles. Additionally, they prepare sites for operations, organize materials for efficient use, and load necessary items into equipment or designated areas. This work includes performing routine maintenance and repairs on equipment using hand tools. After operations conclude, they ensure the work area is clean and free of debris, maintaining a safe and organized environment.

Occupation: First-Line Supervisors of Mechanics, Installers, and Repairers
Summary: This role involves overseeing and coordinating the daily activities of mechanics, installers, and repairers. Key responsibilities include monitoring work progress, reviewing performance, and ensuring adherence to quality and safety standards through inspections and training. This position requires making decisions on task assignments, scheduling, and resource allocation, such as requisitioning necessary materials and parts. Interactions are frequent, involving conferring with team members, management, and potentially customers to resolve issues, provide guidance on services, and address grievances. The role also includes counseling employees, recommending personnel actions, and investigating incidents to maintain efficient operations and a safe working environment.

Occupation: Computer, Automated Teller, and Office Machine Repairers
Summary: These professionals diagnose and fix malfunctioning electronic office equipment. They begin by listening to users to understand the problem, then disassemble devices to inspect components for wear or defects. They use various tools and diagnostic equipment to pinpoint issues, replacing or repairing faulty parts and recalibrating systems. After repairs, they reassemble and test the equipment to ensure proper functioning. They may also install new equipment, configure software, and provide guidance to users on operation and maintenance. Maintaining accurate records of work performed and parts used is also a key responsibility, along with managing inventory and ordering necessary supplies.

Occupation: Radio, Cellular, and Tower Equipment Installers and Repairers
Summary: Individuals in this role are responsible for installing, maintaining, and repairing communication equipment. They interpret technical documents, blueprints, and work orders to guide their actions. Their day involves physically installing components, such as antennas, mounts, and cables, ensuring secure and proper placement. They meticulously test and verify that equipment functions correctly, often using specialized tools to analyze signal strength and network coverage. Following installation or repair, they conduct thorough inspections to confirm all work meets specifications and safety standards. This requires careful coordination, precise execution of tasks, and attention to detail, ensuring reliable communication systems. They also maintain records of their work and document progress through reports and photographs.

Occupation: Telecommunications Equipment Installers and Repairers, Except Line Installers
Summary: These professionals install, set up, and reconfigure communication systems. They meticulously test circuits and components using various tools to diagnose and isolate malfunctions. After identifying issues, they repair or replace faulty equipment, ensuring all connections are adequate and functional. They also perform routine inspections and preventative maintenance to guarantee optimal equipment performance. Collaboration with colleagues is frequent for troubleshooting and resolving complex problems. Additionally, they maintain detailed records of facilities and equipment, adhering to manufacturer specifications and technical documentation. Demonstrating equipment to users and explaining its functionality is also a key responsibility, along with responding to inquiries and complaints.

Individuals in this role perform diagnostic evaluations, maintenance, and repair on various electronic systems. They meticulously read technical documentation like blueprints and manuals to guide installation and assembly processes. Using a range of tools, they connect, adjust, and replace components to ensure proper functionality. Their work involves rigorous testing, both on the ground and through interpreting flight data, to identify and resolve malfunctions. They maintain detailed records of all servicing and repair activities. Coordination with colleagues and engineers is essential for effective operations and problem-solving. This role demands precision in troubleshooting and a commitment to maintaining system integrity through careful inspection and repair.

Occupation: Electric Motor, Power Tool, and Related Repairers
Summary: These professionals diagnose and fix mechanical and electrical issues with various equipment. They meticulously inspect and test components to identify damage, wear, or malfunctions by using diagnostic tools and schematic drawings. After disassembling the equipment, they repair or rebuild defective parts, making precise adjustments and ensuring all connections, wiring, and contacts meet specifications. This often involves cleaning, lubricating, and reassembling components using specialized tools. They also document the repairs performed, parts utilized, and the time taken. Their work requires careful measurement of performance metrics and adherence to detailed repair guides and diagrams to restore functionality and ensure optimal operation of the equipment.

Occupation: Electrical and Electronics Installers and Repairers, Transportation Equipment
Summary: Professionals in this role meticulously inspect and test electrical systems and equipment to identify and diagnose malfunctions. They utilize visual inspections, specialized testing devices, and software to pinpoint issues. Following diagnosis, they adjust, repair, or replace defective components such as wiring and relays, ensuring proper function of ignition, lighting, climate control, and safety systems. This involves splicing wires, soldering connections, and locating and rectifying circuit defects like blown fuses or malfunctioning transistors. They meticulously reassemble and test equipment post-repair, referring to schematics and manufacturer specifications to guide their work. Additionally, they install new components, cut openings, drill holes for fixtures, and maintain detailed service records of all equipment.

Occupation: Electrical and Electronics Repairers, Commercial and Industrial Equipment
Summary: These professionals diagnose and resolve malfunctions in electronic systems and equipment. They meticulously test components, analyze performance data, and use schematics and specifications to identify issues. Responsibilities include calibrating instruments, repairing or replacing defective parts, and ensuring proper installation and setup. They maintain detailed logs of performance, repairs, and maintenance activities, often consulting with operators and colleagues to troubleshoot complex problems. Preventive maintenance is crucial to detect and avert potential issues before they impact operations. These individuals also coordinate with others, manage inventory of necessary parts, and may advise on product performance and improvements, ensuring equipment functions according to prescribed standards.

Occupation: Electrical and Electronics Repairers, Powerhouse, Substation, and Relay
Summary: These professionals inspect and test electrical equipment and circuits to identify and address malfunctions or defects, utilizing diagnostic devices and technical diagrams. They analyze test data to understand performance and the impact of modifications, and they consult with colleagues and documentation to troubleshoot complex issues. When necessary, they isolate defective components and perform repairs or replacements. This role involves maintaining detailed records of inspections, tests, repairs, and preventative maintenance. They also manage inventories of necessary parts and communicate equipment shutdowns to relevant personnel. A key responsibility is ensuring the continued optimal functioning of critical electrical systems through diligent monitoring and proactive upkeep.

Occupation: Electronic Equipment Installers and Repairers, Motor Vehicles
Summary: Professionals in this role install, troubleshoot, and repair various electronic systems within vehicles. They begin by conferring with customers to understand reported issues, then conduct thorough inspections and diagnostic tests using specialized instruments to pinpoint malfunctions. Based on these findings, they meticulously repair or replace faulty components, splice wires, and solder connections as needed. This often involves cutting openings, drilling holes, and modifying interior structures to accommodate new or existing equipment. They also install accessories, ensuring proper function, and may construct custom enclosures for audio components. Throughout the process, they maintain detailed records of tests and repair outcomes, and provide cost estimates for their services.

Professionals in this role are responsible for installing, adjusting, and repairing electronic entertainment equipment. They diagnose and resolve issues by calibrating and testing devices, often using specialized instruments. This involves disassembling equipment to identify and replace faulty components, or positioning and wiring new parts. They confer with clients to understand problems, explain repairs, and provide instructions on proper equipment usage. Maintaining detailed records of service calls, work orders, and maintenance reports is also a key responsibility. Their daily activities require meticulous attention to detail, problem-solving skills, and the ability to interpret technical diagrams and manuals to ensure optimal equipment performance and reception.

Occupation: Security and Fire Alarm Systems Installers
Summary: Professionals in this role install, maintain, and repair systems designed to detect and alert about security or fire-related events. They interpret blueprints and work orders to determine the correct placement of components and wiring paths, often drilling holes and running cables through walls and ceilings. They meticulously connect devices, test circuits, and program system features to ensure optimal performance. When issues arise, they systematically troubleshoot and diagnose problems, making necessary repairs. They also consult with clients to understand their specific needs and demonstrate the functionality of installed systems, explaining how they operate and addressing potential concerns like false alarms.

Professionals in this role are responsible for the meticulous examination and repair of complex mechanical and structural systems. They meticulously inspect components, diagnose issues by reviewing technical documentation and listening to operational feedback, and perform repairs using specialized tools and equipment. This involves replacing worn parts, servicing systems, and ensuring all assemblies function correctly. Maintaining detailed records of all maintenance performed is crucial. They also manage the procurement of necessary parts and materials. A key aspect of the role involves testing repaired systems to guarantee they meet stringent operational standards before certifying them for use, often requiring collaboration with colleagues for precise alignment and installation tasks.

Professionals in this field meticulously restore damaged vehicle exteriors. They begin by examining damage reports and estimates, planning the necessary repair sequence. Using a variety of hand and power tools, they remove damaged sections, including panels and glass, and meticulously shape metal by beating out dents and smoothing surfaces. They also straighten frames using specialized equipment. For more complex repairs, they may work with composite materials or fit and weld replacement parts. Following repairs, they prepare surfaces by sanding and priming before applying paint. Finally, they conduct thorough inspections, test-drive vehicles to confirm proper handling and alignment, and reassemble any removed interior components.

Professionals in this role meticulously prepare vehicle glass areas by cleaning and priming surfaces, ensuring optimal adhesion for repairs or replacements. They carefully select necessary tools and materials, then expertly remove damaged glass components using specialized techniques.  Attention to detail is paramount as they prepare the vehicle frame, manage environmental factors like temperature and humidity, and meticulously install new glass.  Finally, they reassemble all associated parts, ensuring a weatherproof and secure fit, while also verifying the proper functioning of related mechanisms. Their work demands precision to restore vehicle integrity and safety.

Individuals in this role diagnose, repair, and maintain vehicles by performing comprehensive inspections to identify issues. They test components and systems, often using specialized diagnostic equipment, to pinpoint malfunctions. A significant part of the job involves discussing vehicle problems with customers and supervisors, providing repair estimates, and planning work procedures. Tasks include repairing or replacing worn or defective parts, adjusting systems to meet performance standards, and performing routine maintenance such as oil changes and tune-ups. They meticulously follow checklists to ensure all critical areas are examined, from engine components to electrical systems. Maintaining a clean workspace and ensuring all repairs are tested for proper function are also key responsibilities.

Occupation: Bus and Truck Mechanics and Diesel Engine Specialists
Summary: These professionals diagnose, repair, and maintain heavy vehicles and diesel engines. They meticulously inspect various vehicle components, including brakes and steering systems, to identify issues and ensure safe operation. Using specialized tools and diagnostic equipment, they pinpoint malfunctions by examining parts, listening to sounds, and analyzing instrument readings. They then perform necessary adjustments, repairs, and overhauls, which can involve disassembling and rebuilding engines, transmissions, or other complex mechanical systems. Routine maintenance tasks like oil changes and lubrication are also part of their responsibilities. After repairs, they often test drive vehicles to confirm proper functioning and adherence to specifications.

Occupation: Farm Equipment Mechanics and Service Technicians
Summary: These professionals diagnose and repair a variety of mechanical equipment. They examine machinery, listen to operational sounds, and review reports to identify issues. After diagnosing a malfunction, they dismantle defective components, clean and lubricate parts, and repair or replace them using various tools and techniques. This can involve fabricating new parts, welding, or working with sheet metal. They test repaired equipment, making necessary adjustments to ensure proper function. Detailed records of repairs and parts used are maintained. They also perform routine maintenance, such as lubrication, and may transport tools and equipment to work sites for on-location repairs.

Occupation: Mobile Heavy Equipment Mechanics, Except Engines
Summary: Individuals in this role diagnose, adjust, repair, and overhaul mechanical, hydraulic, and pneumatic equipment. They meticulously inspect machines, read technical drawings and manuals, and use diagnostic tools to identify faults and malfunctions. A key responsibility involves dismantling equipment, examining parts for damage or wear, and fitting new components or repairing existing ones. This includes tasks like welding, soldering, and fabricating parts as needed. They test and adjust repaired equipment to ensure optimal performance, adhering to specifications. Additionally, they perform routine maintenance such as cleaning and lubrication, manage parts inventory, and maintain service records. Some may also oversee and guide other workers involved in assembly or disassembly.

These professionals diagnose, adjust, repair, and overhaul various types of rail cars. They meticulously inspect components such as bearings, seals, wheels, and coupler assemblies to identify defects, wear, and damage, both internally and externally. Based on these inspections, they repair or replace worn or defective parts using a variety of tools. This often involves removing and reinstalling major units, fabricating and installing fittings, and performing scheduled maintenance. They also test units for operability before and after repairs, making necessary adjustments to ensure proper function. Additionally, their responsibilities include maintaining detailed records of conditions and work performed, and sometimes painting exteriors and interiors.

Individuals in this role meticulously inspect, diagnose, and repair complex mechanical and electrical systems. They disassemble components to pinpoint issues, using specialized tools and gauges, then replace or recondition faulty parts. Routine maintenance, such as fluid changes and filter replacements, is also a key responsibility. Technicians test repairs by starting engines, monitoring performance indicators like temperature and vibration, and conducting operational tests on the water. They meticulously document all inspections, tests, and work performed, ensuring functionality and adherence to performance standards. This role requires precise adjustments to various controls and systems, followed by thorough verification of proper operation and safety.

Individuals in this role focus on diagnosing and repairing motorized two-wheeled vehicles. They meticulously examine these vehicles, listening to engines and conferring with customers to identify issues. Using a variety of tools, they dismantle engines and other components, replacing or repairing defective parts such as brakes, transmissions, or ignition systems. They perform tasks like tire maintenance, component adjustments, and accessory installation. After repairs, they reassemble units, ensure proper alignment, and test functionality to confirm the vehicle is operating correctly and safely. Their work involves careful inspection, precise repair, and thorough testing to restore vehicles to optimal working condition.

Occupation: Outdoor Power Equipment and Other Small Engine Mechanics
Summary: These professionals diagnose, adjust, and repair small engines that power various equipment. They meticulously examine engines, dismantling them to identify and replace or repair defective parts using a variety of tools. Routine maintenance, such as cleaning, oiling, and tuning systems, is also a key responsibility. They often interact with customers to understand issues, provide repair estimates, and explain maintenance procedures. After completing repairs, they thoroughly test and inspect engines to ensure proper functioning. Detailed record-keeping of repairs, time, and parts used is essential. They may also be involved in selling parts and equipment, requiring knowledge of available options and their applications.

Individuals in this role diagnose and resolve issues with mechanical systems. They inspect components, identify problems, and perform necessary repairs, often involving disassembly and reassembly of parts. This includes adjusting and replacing various mechanisms, ensuring proper alignment and functionality. They also assemble new units and install new parts and accessories according to specifications. Responsibilities extend to routine maintenance, such as cleaning and lubrication, to ensure optimal performance. Additionally, they may advise individuals on appropriate selections based on their needs and assist with sales of related items.

Professionals in this field meticulously diagnose and repair various systems within vehicles. They meticulously inspect components, identify malfunctions, and perform necessary adjustments or overhauls. This involves a range of activities, from repairing electrical wiring and plumbing to servicing heating and cooling systems. They consult with clients, review work orders, and utilize technical manuals to understand the scope of repairs. After completing work, they test systems to ensure proper functionality and often explain the operation of repaired components to customers. Their responsibilities also include maintaining precise records of parts needed, estimating costs, and planning efficient work procedures to ensure quality outcomes and customer satisfaction.

Professionals in this role focus on maintaining and repairing vehicle tires. They begin by safely raising vehicles using specialized equipment, then meticulously unbolting and removing wheels. Their work involves identifying tire damage, locating punctures, and performing repairs by sealing or patching them. This includes reassembling tires onto wheels, balancing them by adding counterweights, and ensuring proper inflation based on size and ply. They also perform routine tasks such as rotating tires for even wear, replacing valve stems, and assisting with other vehicle maintenance duties. Maintaining a clean workspace is also part of their daily responsibilities.

These professionals install, service, and repair automated and mechanical door systems. They carefully inspect job sites to assess conditions and determine the best approach for installations, consulting blueprints and diagrams to guide their work. Day-to-day activities involve assembling and fastening tracks, installing frames, and attaching various door components, including openers, closers, and seals. They also diagnose and fix issues by repairing or replacing worn or broken parts, often fabricating replacements as needed. This requires meticulous work, using a range of tools and equipment to ensure doors function correctly and safely. They may also handle administrative tasks like completing paperwork and collecting payments upon completion of services.

Occupation: Control and Valve Installers and Repairers, Except Mechanical Door
Summary: Individuals in this role focus on the installation, maintenance, and repair of mechanical regulating and controlling devices. They regularly disassemble equipment, diagnose issues, and perform necessary repairs using various tools. This includes lubricating moving parts to ensure smooth operation and recording detailed information about the work performed, such as test outcomes and materials utilized. They must carefully monitor equipment performance and apply troubleshooting and repair skills to maintain functionality and prevent future problems. Decision-making is crucial when assessing the condition of devices and determining the appropriate course of action for repairs or replacements, all while ensuring proper operation and functionality of the controlled systems.

Occupation: Heating, Air Conditioning, and Refrigeration Mechanics and Installers
Summary: These professionals install, repair, and maintain systems that control the temperature and air quality of indoor environments. They inspect existing systems, troubleshoot malfunctions, and diagnose problems by testing components and consulting with users. After identifying issues or preparing for installations, they repair or replace defective parts, braze or solder joints, and connect wiring and components according to specifications. They also perform regular maintenance tasks, such as cleaning and replacing filters, to ensure optimal system performance. They study blueprints and manufacturer recommendations to guide their work, ensuring compliance with standards and proper system balancing. They accurately document their work, including materials used and any encountered issues.

Diagnose, adjust, and repair a variety of electric and gas household appliances. Examine appliances to detect malfunctions, and consult manuals and diagrams to identify and resolve problems. Replace defective parts, ensuring proper functionality through testing and adjustments. Install new appliances, ensuring correct setup and initial operation. Communicate with customers to understand issues, provide estimates, recommend repair or replacement options, and instruct on proper usage and care. Maintain records of work performed and manage necessary parts inventory. Respond to emergency service needs, prioritizing safety and timely resolution of issues. Bill customers and collect payments upon completion of services.

Professionals in this field are responsible for maintaining and repairing complex machinery. They meticulously examine components for wear or defects, troubleshoot operational issues by observing and testing equipment, and diagnose problems using diagnostic devices and analyzing error messages. Based on their findings, they disassemble, repair, or replace malfunctioning parts, often involving precise adjustments or fabrication through cutting and welding. They meticulously reassemble and test the machinery to ensure proper functioning, documenting all repairs and parts used. They also interpret technical manuals and blueprints to ensure correct installation and operation, and may instruct operators on equipment functions.

Workers in this field perform routine inspections and maintenance on machinery. They read work orders and specifications to identify equipment needing attention, then proceed with lubrication, cleaning, or part replacement. This involves dismantling machinery, using various tools and equipment to remove defective parts, and installing new ones according to precise standards. They also reassemble machines after repairs and monitor their operation to ensure efficiency and detect any emerging issues. Collaboration with colleagues is common when moving or repairing equipment. Record-keeping of production and maintenance activities is essential, as is managing inventory and requisitioning necessary supplies to maintain operational readiness.

Individuals in this role are responsible for the assembly, installation, and dismantling of machinery and equipment. They interpret technical drawings and plans to accurately position and secure components, often using a variety of hand and power tools. This involves precisely aligning parts, adjusting clearances, and fastening elements through methods such as bolting, welding, or riveting. They also perform essential maintenance, including lubrication and the replacement of worn or defective parts, to ensure optimal mechanical operation. Troubleshooting and repairing mechanical, electrical, or hydraulic systems are key duties. This work requires careful measurement, precision, and the ability to safely move heavy equipment using specialized tools and techniques.

Individuals in this role focus on the construction and repair of specialized thermal equipment.
